description.header: OpenBuilds is the new community for sharing open source machine projects and concept builds!
description.text: OpenBuilds team saw a need for a place to share open source machine project builds with each other. A single resource where these builds belong. So we created OpenBuilds to be that place.

description.header: Our goal is to make sharing open source builds as fun and easy as possible.
description.text: OpenBuilds is the place to share open source builds, projects and ideas with like minded people. So, if you want to share your latest build with a community that loves to build and give it the attention it deserves as a build then you will definitely want to be a part of the OpenBuilds community. our motto is:

description.header: Dream it - Build it - Share it

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PLA.  I used 1.2mm edges to add a little strength to it.

description.text:
A couple of years ago I purchased an Energizer headlamp, HD5L33AE to be exact. At some point the plastic piece that holds the strap into the headlamp broke and the lamp would no longer stay on the band. I messaged Energizer about a replacement part and was basically told that they do not keep parts, but were happy to send me a coupon for a certain amount off the purchase of another headlamp. Not exactly my idea of a solution, but they were nice enough to put the coupon in the mail. Well I am not one to toss out a perfectly good item, so this is one of the first things I have worked on with my new 3d printer.

This doesn't have the sleek lines of the original part, but fits my lamp perfectly and even matches up with the ratcheting piece on the lamp. I printed mine with 1.2mm shell thickness, .2 layers and 50% infill. I also did bridging/support type: Everywhere. I then ran this through Cura. Once printed it took a couple of minutes for me to clean out the bridging, and also smooth the edges. There are pictures of this printed and also on the lamp with the strap back in place.

My first version I had to increase the hole diameter for the small pegs on the lamp, and I also added a couple of mm around the peg holes for a little more strength. On my first attempt the holes were so close in diameter one side split. I attribute that to the size of the holes and also that I only printed with 20% infill. That's why in the second attempt I went up on the infill, added a couple mm more around the peg holes and also increased the peg holes to 2.1mm diameter. They fit perfectly now. One last thing, I will probably be putting some foam or moleskin on the back where it touches your head, just for comfort.

Also pictured is the original mount that broke. The second picture is so you can see which headlamp this is. Not sure if this will fit others. I measured the distance between the pegs as 59mm if that helps.

Everything was designed in FreeCAD 1.6 and exported to stl.

MonoPrice Maker Select V2

.2

50%

Autocad 2015

One of the most important holidays in Mexico and the one that marks the beginning of the Christmas season is December 12th, the day of Our Lady of Guadalupe.

According to the story, in December 1531 the Virgin Mary appeared in Mexico. One of the miracles attributed to her visit was the appearance of roses in the Hill of Tepeyac, a place which would be covered in snow during that time.

So, inspired by this story and the concept of making 3D printed snowflakes I decided to make this design. I made two different versions, one for single-extruder printers and other that can be printed using dual extruders.

title: Miasma - 5x Atomizer Stand - With Leak Catcher Juice Well v2.0

description.text:
v2.0 Update

  • Separated juice wells (request)
  • Increased the juice well depth (request)
  • Decreased the 510 holder inner diameter (7mm)
  • Increased overall height
  • Increased the angle of the well graduation (request)

The Miasma Atty Stand

  • Room for 5 Atomizers/Drippers up to 24.5mm
  • Non-screwdown 510 pin holder
  • Graduated leak well, to move e-liquid away from the center pin
  • High walls to contain any leaks
  • Slightly higher 510 holder, to keep the Atty/Dripper up and away from any overflow

The Design

This is my first ever design, and as Vaping is my hobby, I thought it best to make something I want.

The design is mostly inspired by my ups and downs with my Vape gear. I've had my share of leaks and overflows, and have gotten a little sick of the cleanup in the bottom of the cupboard. I wanted something that would keep my decks clean and safe, as well as capture any leaked e-liquid.

I also had an issue where all of my local Vape shops only ever stocked the single aluminium stands, and only ever gave them away for gifts etc.

In the end, I needed something that would hold a minimum of 3x Attys, and contain any leaks. The design was revised a few times, just to get the everything the way I like it.

Re-Use

I fully embrace the CC-BY-SA Licence, and would love to see people make it better; improve; change; and customize my Atty Stand.

If you do, please shoot me a link, so I can see what improvements and changes you've made, so I can get ideas to upgrade my build!

I hope you find this model useful!

title: Prusa X Belt - Extruder Fix (keeps the belt away from the stepper motor)

description.text:
this is my 3th sketchup creation today! ;o) on my prusa mendel, iam not able to mount the extruder in another way... so the x belt always grind on the stepper motor of the extruder. this creation keeps the belt away from the motor. you need materials: 1.) 2x M8 nuts
2.) 1x M8 treaded rod
3.) 1x M3 nut
4.) 2x M3 washers
5.) 1x M3x20 screw
6.) 1x 608z bearing
7.) 2x big M8 washers
8.) 3x small M8 washers

comments.text:
I had this problem too when I built my prusa I2.
Just have to turn the extruder to get the motor to the oppsite side, and cut a lil bit the belt fixation to fix the big wheel contact...
comments.author: Dexerit

comments.text:
i fixed it now with the thingiverse thing: J-HEAD MOUNTING PLATE
with it, my jhead hold stable in place and the motor is 5mm higher then the x-belt.
comments.author: Dexerit

comments.text:
thank you for that info.. i didnt think about it.
its just 1mm push from the motor.. but i see, at the ends it pushes greater to the belt.
comments.author: ooxtcoo

comments.text: This modification changes the geometry and thus the length of your belt as it moves back and forth. You should be able to feel the difference between having the pulley in the center (belt will be looser) vs having it near the end (it will get tighter). This change in belt tension means that your belt will stretch and wear out faster, and also that your steps/mm value will change slightly as the length of the belt changes, causing dimensionally-inaccurate prints.

I designed this to be a template for cutting a 1/8th inch (3mm) aluminum sheet. It could be printed as well . I will create a duct for the single fan model when I have fabricated the carriage. If the cooling is sufficient I mostly not design a duct for the rear.

As you can see its not as bulky as it looks, and compared to my current setup with a 70mm fan blocking my view this looks a lot neater.

(update 12/17/2016)
Added new versions of carriages with the fan duct mounting holes in them. Also added the front fan duct design although the nozzle height varies from printer to printer so you'll need to scale them. (They only take 1.3hrs to print at 100% fill and .2 layer height.) I had though about using the front fan as the heat-break cooking fan but did not design this.

(Update 1/24/2017)
Added a new fan support that includes a air filter assembly. I just use an air conditioning filter and cut it to size, but you might be able to use something like a coffee filter, The benefit here is it should aid in filtering your print fumes and protect your fans from getting dirty.

description.text:
The swivel pi zero case has inspired me to create a swivel SD card holder.

This locks into place to securely store up to 6 SD cards and 2 Micro SD cards.

I really enjoy the ease of use that a swivel case has. By adding a dovetail groove and a few SD card slots i've created something that helps me and hopefully others transport their storage media.

Hope you all enjoy :)

Any tips or feedback are appreciated.

Printer:

XYZ davinci

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.35

Notes:

Please be sure to print the bottom case with SD card holders facing up.
And print the lid with its circular peg facing up.

Higher resolutions can be used without problem.

Print assembly and use.

Step 1. Insert cylindrical lid peg into hole with about an 1/8in gap between the case and lid.

Step 2. Slide the parts together with the dovetail groove.

step 3. Press down on top of the case near circular hole to get rid of 1/8in gap.

Step 4. You're done! Enjoy!

For taking swivel case lid off just perform these steps completely backwards!

Dovetail groove

Depending on your print quality, you may need to slide the case through its channel a few times to smooth things out.

It's purposely designed to be a little tight, but should not require a ton of force to open.

title: Weedeater Line Spool for TroyBilt 4 Stroke

description.text:
Next up, fixing my weedeater. Troy-Bilt TB6040 XP. It's a four stroke weedeater, and a couple of months ago when weedeating the line feeder came apart and the two little metal spools went flying. I happened to spot one a few weeks later, but the other is missing in action. So with my new printer I decided I would print a couple of them up and give it a try. First, use these at your own risk. I only attempted this because I can't find substitutes without buying an entire line spool assembly and that isn't going to happen. I printed the first set, but they only lasted about one weedeating session. The second set I went in and reduced the diameter of the inner hole in an attempt to beef them up a little and give them some more plastic to wear down. I have not used the second set in the weedeater yet as the first design is still intact. I printed these with 100% infill as I wanted them as solid as possible. I also used supports so that the upper part would print properly. They are fairly easy to clean.

When weedeating I did break one of the first two, but think it's because I hit something with it. I had another set I had just printed so I put them in and they lasted the rest of the session. The one that didn't break I took out and took a picture of and you can see the wear. That's what spurred me to go in and beef up the inside hole.

WeedeaterLineSpool_TroyBilt4Stroke.stl matches the original more closely.
WeedeaterLineSpool_TroyBilt4Stroke_smallerID.stl should be a little tougher and last longer, but I haven't tried these yet. They might be a little harder to get the line spooled initially since the inner diameter is smaller.

Again, use at your own risk. These will be nowhere near as sturdy as the metal replacements, but might get your yard finished, then you can spend the rest of the evening trying to find replacements. Make sure and wear eye, or preferably face protection at all times when weedeating. I also wear long sleeves, pants and boots.

Designed in FreeCAD 1.6.

title: Direct Geared Belted Extruder V2 - 1,75mm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Direct Geared Belted Extruder V2 - for 1,75mm

If you are looking for a bowden version, you should go see my Belted Extruder v.3 for 1.75 instead.

Changes from V1

Rotated the Extruder 90 degrees to face forward instead of to the left.
Some user have had problems with the left facing model hitting Z-rods etc. I made spacers for that eventuality, but V2 eleminates this issue.

New X-Carriage for V2

You are going to need my remixed X-Carriage for Direct Geared Belted Extruder V2 for this Extruder.
It is listed seperately as it is a Remix and thus have different licens on it.
Photos shows the X-Carriage mouted on the Extruder.

Key features
  • Compact highly accurate, easy to use and -install Direct Geared Geared Belted Extruder for all 1,75mm filaments.
  • Gearings 1:3.75
  • Weight including motor: 320g - This is including motor, all gears, belt, screws, nuts etc..
    Please note that a standard normal Nema 17 weights 290g in itself, so 320g is VERY light
  • Only Quality items used for longelevity and better Accuracy.
  • No exotic, hard to find expensive parts used.
  • Set and Forget Idler system - try it! :)
  • Prusa compatible mount hole spacing.
  • Silent running due to belt operation.
  • Mount holes for Optional usage of Expansions.
Expansions options
  • Option to mount sensors or other expansion behind hotend.
  • Cooling solution can be mounted on Expansion slots instead of on hotend
  • Opton to mount cable management, Motor-cover, fans and other expansions next to motor.

Usage Requirment

While this Direct-Drive Belted Extruder 1,75mm (v2) has standard hole mount spacing of 23mm center to center of the mount holes, and you most likely can use it as it is, I recommend you do one of the following, where the first is the preferred option:

  1. Use my modified X-Carriage for Direct Geared Belted Extruder V2.
  2. Remove 1-2mm of the top-center of your existing Carriage.
  3. Use spacer-plate/s to put between your existing carriage and the extruder.

Buy one?

I am selling these. Also just the metal parts. Drop me a message if interested. I live in Denmark and can ship for DKkr 35 in Denmark, but let me know where you live, and we'll see.

3D model and files?

I do not offer up the extruder in other fileformats than STL, but you can see the model on MyHub on Autodesk's servers.

Printer:

CrossBot My Version

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm max

Infill:

25% or more

Notes:
I have provided 2 models:
  • 1 with support and 1 without for people who'd like to setup support on their own.
Other Settings
  • 3 Borders/Perimeters.
  • 3 Top/Bottom -layers or more.
  • I have printed in PLA and PETG without resize modifiers in slizer. If you use ABS you might need to enlarge your object in the slizer.

I used Autodesk Fision 360

There is a common misconception that Autodesk Fusion 360 costs money, but it truely is totally free to use for private people and small businesses and not just students and teachers.

Once installe you are asked to accept the licens and just put in you are private person or small business as appropriate. Once a year you have to re-accept the licens.

Also check out their free app for phones and tablets which can be used to view and share your items.

BOM
  • 60GT-2 Pulley
  • 16GT-2 or 20GT-2 Pulley.
  • E3D Hobbed Bolt - Hobb-Goblin-8mm-Shaft.
  • 172-GT2 Belt.
  • 0-1x m6 Push-Fitting for 1.75mm filament.
  • 2x 20mm steel springs. 1-1.2mm thick.
  • 3x 608 bearings. 8x22x7 - Type doesn't matter.
  • Various m3 nuts, screws and spacers - Details below
Detailed Screwn/Nut BOM
  • 13-17x M3 nuts (if using cable management or motor-covers)
  • 4x m3 spacers - Fasten Motor
  • 4x m3 8mm - Expansions bar.
  • 4x m3 10mm - Fasten Motor.
  • 3x m3 16mm - Hotend Fastener and Idler.
  • 2x m3 25mm - Idler and Spring Frame joints.
  • 2x m3 50mm - Socket Head Screws, Partially Threaded.
  • 4x m4 - Lock-nuts
<h5>Addons</h5>

Everything for my Belted Extruders, including Mounting brackets can be found in the my Collection: Belted Extruders by Dintid

Addons are trickling in, so hit follow or just check back now and then :)

<h3>Calibrate Steps/mm</h3>

A few stepper examples. Remember to do a proper measurement yourself. I have rounded the numbers up/down.

When using:

  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/32 multistepping + 0.9degree motor = 2050 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/16 multistepping + 0.9 degree motor = 1025 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/32 multistepping + 1.8 degree motor = 1025 steps/mm
  • 16-GT2 + 60-GT2 pulleys + 1/16 multistepping + 1.8 degree motor = 510 steps/mm
Insert m3 nuts into the two parts. Insert Spring Tightener part and the springs. Assemble the rest and make sure the m3 screws are FLUSH with the bottom of the Spring-frame

<h4>Choosing stepper motor</h4>

This can be a complicated step unto itself. I am using a 0.9 degree Nema 17 on a 32bit 24v platform. It works very nicely.

If you are using a 12v platform, and especially if your 12v platform is an Arduino Mega or other 8bit controller, you should look at a 1.8 degree motor instead.

The motor I am using:
  • I am using Nema 17 "pancake" as in flat model.
  • Manufacturer Part Number: 17HM08-1204S
    0.9deg Nema 17 Stepper Motor 1.2A 11Ncm / 15.6oz.in / 1.12Kg.cm 42x42x20mm
    I found it on german ebay.
  • You can reuse whatever Nema 17 you might have, but using a smaller motor dramatically decreases the weight.
Picking a nema 17 1.8 degree motor

Look for a motor between 1.2 and 2amp with 15Ncm / 21oz.in / 1.5kg.cm

Doing it the scientific way:

If you want to do it the scientific way, you should head over to Duet3D and read their piece on Considerations when choosing stepper motors.

Metal Parts (refer to BOM for precise listing) Do not skimp on Hobbed Bolt. Right one is E3D.. other one is from respectable local shop... Just go E3D. Measurements to create Extensions

title: Soldering Iron Tip Cleaner Mesh Ball Holder Thingy

description.text: I do quite a bit of soldering w/ my new RC quadcopter hobby and I do hate adding water to my tip cleaning sponge all the time, but it does work so well. I've eyed up these copper mesh ball holders for soldering iron tip cleaning and well....here's my iteration of it. I got some copper'ish cleaning mesh balls from the dollar store and they work pretty good. It's not as clean as a wet sponge but it gets me by. I'm pretty happy with my dollar investment. I cut the mesh ball in half and works great. The full mesh ball will fit but cleaning the tip of the iron isn't as easy as you'll have a harder time pushing it into the mesh as its tightly packed in there. The bottom is indented so you can add tacky putty to hold it down. or use double sided tape if you need to. enjoy

title: Camera Handle Pistol Grip Handheld Stabilizer

description.text: Have you ever wished to print a camera grip instead of buying a camera grip? This is it. Standard 1/4"-20 thread 3/8" length hex bolts accepted. Thumbwheel included with print (so you don't have to tighten everything by hand or with a wrench). Insert screw (m2x8) optional but highly recommended.

Printer:

Generic Kossell

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2mm is enough

Infill:

25%+, pistol grips feel better in the hand with extra weight

Notes:

please note that this grip can be printed without supports or printed filament cooling, but you may have minor deformation of the grip on the bottom side. This is okay for most peoples' hands, and I haven't found it to be an issue. This also slightly increases the chance for print failure due to collision (overhands tend to warp upwards); be careful when printing the bottom half of the grip.
(this is a minor word of caution, and it is very acceptable to do something else while this is printing)

Parts Needed
  • 1/4"-20 thread, 3/8" length hex bolt
    https://www.mcmaster.com/#92240a535
  • M2 thread, 8mm length pan head machine screw
    https://www.mcmaster.com/#92005a029
  • (Optional) Adhesive-backed 60A Durometer 1/32" thick Neoprene Rubber with crisscross texture (doesn't have to be exact)
    https://www.mcmaster.com/#8445k61
Assembly
  1. Group the hex bolt with the thumbwheel
  2. Inserting the group into the handle
  3. Push the threaded portion of the hex bolt out of the hole in the handle. Make sure you align the hex head with the cutout on the thumbwheel.
  4. You can either glue in or screw in the insert.
  5. (Optional) You can attach buy some rubber to secure the camera better and ease disassembly

description.text:
This is a DeLorean model that was found on the Sketchup 3d Warehouse made by mandun under the title "The Time Machine"

I liked this model so much I scaled it down, and took it apart and modified it slightly so it would print. Please be advised that this is a complicated print and not for the light hearted.

Thank you so much for the beautiful model mandun!!!

Fixes

  • Fixed incorrect back mesh (left exhaust had some artifacts)
  • Fixed missing meshes on left door
  • Split back up further to make it easier to print

title: Tevo Tarantula Trust Bearing Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to support my z axis rods, and I had some 26mm OD 11 ID thrust-bearings lying around. I also wanted them to be aluminum. So I made these guides to act as bushings between the rod and bearing/washers. I also included a bracket however there are much better designs for printed supports. When I purchased my dual z upgrade rods I also bought matching couplers. So rather then print couplers for this thing I have cut my old spring couplers into three pieces so that I can use them. Pics will fallow once printed and assembled.

(Update 12/15/2016 Added a file with thicker bottom of Inner guide, and added an outer bearing guide with screw hole, to keep it from spinning.)

description.text:
My family has traditionally made these Gingerbread Houses, and now that I have turned them into easy to use cookie cutters, now you can too. I am sharing the pattern for these houses that my father created, and the recipe and instructions that my mother made. I have enjoyed building and decorating one house every Christmas since I was 18 months old.

The recipe is for a traditional gingerbread which is great tasting and a durable construction material for these houses. The houses can be baked and stored, ready to be decorated, for up to a year. Also included is our royal frosting recipe which works wonderfully as a strong cement to hold the structure together. This is also used to hold the decorations in place.

To decorate these houses use a pastry bag with a #17 nozzle to apply the frosting as you go, in locations where you wish to attach the candy. Be sure not to apply the frosting before you are ready to place the candy as it will harden and make it impossible to bond the candy to the surface. Decorate with any selection of holiday candy you wish, above is a picture of last years candy selection at our decorating session. Hard sugar candies such as candy canes or ribbon candy, will melt within a few days once attached, because of this they are not recommended if you plan on keeping this around for a few weeks. Once you are finished decorating the house you should wrap it in saran wrap to help keep the gingerbread from absorbing the moist winter air.

Attached to this are the files needed for the cookie cutters, and a pdf format for the recipes, baking, and assembly instructions.

Soon I will be uploading a miniature version of the house as well as a barn styled house.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Any

Notes:

Please use PLA for this print.

You need to print out one of each of the 7 cutters. They should all be straightforward to print.

When printing it is crucial that the blade be strong, otherwise there is some risk of breaking after continued use. The blade is designed for 0.8mm thickness (2 perimeters with a 0.4mm nozzle) so be sure that you get at least 2 passes with your code.

The parts are all labeled on the bottom print surface to help you distinguish between them once printed out.
The only post processing needed would be to remove any stringing that is caused during the printing process. Although harmless, you probably don't want to be baking these into your houses.

description.text:
This was inspired by Chaos Core Tech and his wife, they have an awesome Youtube channel with a ton of 3D Printing tutorials and advice. https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVmyytnqQrcTg1WRFXTo14Q
They are the ones that got me into painting my models in the first place, then I realised that I needed somewhere to put my brushes to dry, after cleaning. So I made a stand.
The stand then progressed into a storage box with stand.
With this I also have all my brushes to hand and also a stand for them between colours, rather than laying them down and creating a mess.

This is the coupling piece between the metal shaft of the mixing wand and the plastic motor connection on the body. You can buy a replacement (for example here http://braun-service-station.de/Braun-Ersatzteile-Zubehoer/Ersatzteile-Haushalt/Ersatzteile-Mixstaebe/Ersatzteile-Stabmixer-Typ-4191/Plastikkupplung-fuer-Plastik--und-Metallschaft-Braun-Stabmixer-Typ-4191--67050811.html), but I had already mocked this up before I even bothered to look. I included the SCAD file for others to tweak. It includes an optional gap for a rubber o ring that is present in the original piece. Unfortunately it didn't print well for me with the gap. Fortunately it appears to work without the ring. The blender_repair_gap.stl is the higher resolution file with the accurate shaft dimensions and the gap for the o-ring.

The STL contains an increased shaft width of 4mm over the actual 3.5mm dimensions of the shaft.  This is to make up for the tolerance of my Thing-O-Matic.
I also hade to slow down the feed rate to 10mm/s to get something that worked, and then I had to do some light sanding and carving to the piece to get it to fit in the motor hausing without sticking.

This is a model of the Sommerswerd based off the illustration from the original game book.

It's a simple model which comes in 5 parts with an additional 6mm rod needed as a central peg for the blade. You can make do with a simple 6mm diameter wooden dowel or print the attached rod with high infill settings.

Assembly instructions in one of the attached images.

In memory of Joe Dever - thanks for all the magicial adventures we had in Magnamud! For Sommerlund and the Kai! =)

• Is your Printrbot Simple Z end stop adjustment screw just a little too short?

  • Did you know by turning the Z end stop adjustment screw 45 degrees your height will change by 0.1mm?
    • This thing will thread onto the end of your Z end stop adjustment screw to give you 10mm more length. Also, every 45 degrees there is a mark to indicate a change of 0.1mm in height so you can more easily see how much you are adjusting. 2014-02-17, RevA: Reduced diameter to help clear XL versions, and reduced contact surface where it engages the switch. The large flat bottom of the original design is not forgiving if installed slightly crooked. Rev. A is more forgiving with it's smaller contact area, and adds 5mm more to the overall height.

Thread the existing nut up the screw about 12mm.
Thread this onto the end of the Z end stop adjustment screw until it stops.
Bring the existing nut back down to lock it all in place.

Pencil Launcher
https://youtu.be/NQ93R2Apu_g
For safety reasons, only pencils with a soft eraser in front should be used. The sharp point goes into the launcher.
Like in the rocket launcher http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1948686 two rubber bands take care of a powerful launch. The launcher has three parts, the tube, a moving cylinder and a fixed part which is attached to the tube with three small screws. Push the pencil, point forward, into the hole of the fixed part, stretching the rubber bands and push until the lock clicks in at the end of the tube. This might not work if the tube is not flat. Some sanding will eliminate that problem. Look for a safe landing place, point the launcher in that direction and push both lock pins simultaneously to the inside of the tube: You have ignition!
Tip: Print the moving part with 100% infill to get strong and flexible springs. For the other parts, 20% infill is O.K.
For a shorter range or shorter pencils, just cut off a piece of the tube.

description.text:
As an homage to my father and his first tractor I proudly present my next project, the OpenRC tractor. It's an open source 1/10 scale replica of an original Ebro 160D tractor. I designed it all from scratch and 3D printed all parts. Then, I added some electronics, nuts and bolts and I made it work!
I also prepared some basic instructions and BOM, so you can easily print and assemble your own tractor. It is designed to be easy to print and no supports are needed for any part.

Points to bear in mind:

As part of optional parts, you'll find different optional plates. There is one for Spain and one for Sweden because there are already OpenRC tractors in both countries. If you print your tractor and you would like to have a plate with your country letters, write a comment and I will try to add it.

Recommended motors have poor torque. They work on smooth surfaces but not off-road. I have prepared a mod to upgrade the tractor with a more powerful motor. Check updates.
I used same bearings as OpenRC formula1 to make it easier for those who already have the F1.
And you know what the best thing is? You can design your own tools!

With OpenRC tractor, possibilities are endless, new tools keep coming...so stay tuned!! (see below updates and get more details at (http://www.makitpro.com)
Videos in action
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HJo-eUfV0fI
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dlf3Jw0A2M4
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nwje55RMaBw

There is a lot of work put into this project, hope you like it and to see your prints soon!

UPDATE 1:

Get the tractor trailer at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967778
Get the motor mod to use a standard 540 size motor at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967812

UPDATE 2:

Get the tractor fertilizer at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967859

UPDATE 3:

Check updates at http://makitpro.com/index.php/openrc-tractor/

Thanks to ZYYX 3D printer for sponsoring the project. OpenRC tractor project follows OpenRC by Daniel Noree's philosophy and it is licensed under CC-BY-SA 4.0.

Hey citkit!
Sorry that you have problems assembling the tractor.
You need the ESC to control speed of the motor.
First, please be sure you read the FAQ section of the tractor's main page where you can find some answers to your questions and some pictures of my connections. http://makitpro.com/index.php/openrc-tractor/openrc-tractor-faq/
The links you provide, are for the servo reverser and one of them includes a Y cable. For the tractor, you only need ONE reverser and ONE Y cable. Check this post for more instructions: http://makitpro.com/index.php/2016/11/26/openrc-tractor-connections/
comments.author: citkit

comments.text: Thank you so much ı take your advice.ı have an another question about rear arms how can use 3ch .ı bought 3ch transmittor .can you explain
comments.author: Makitpro

comments.text:
With 3ch radio, use third channel to connect the rear arms. The rear arms work with two servos. One of them need to be reversed with the reverser. Then the other servo and the reversed, have to be joint with a Y cable. Now you'll only have one cable coming from the rear arms, and that is the one you have to connect to the third channel.
In the FAQ section you'll find pictures and more information: http://makitpro.com/index.php/openrc-tractor/openrc-tractor-faq/#faq3

title: 30mm Convertible Fan Mount (MP Select Mini) Incomplete

description.text:
UPDATE
Current Models have tolerance issues that I didn't catch in the simulation. Basically, the outer housing is too tight for the reproductive capabilities of my Mini, and I assume others will have the same issue. I will upload corrected models asap, but in the meantime, feel free to play around with these yourselves. Sorry if anyone wasted filament on these models, but a vigorous sanding of the internals will correct the problem.

As I get farther into 3D printing, I want to work with different materials and take on tougher prints. Doing so requires a lot of time screwing around with my fan, trying to get air where I need it when I need it, and keep it away when I don't.

I had seen a couple of projects that involved part fans you could turn on and off, and I invested in a serious fan upgrade. While I was waiting for the new fan to make it to Texas from the other side of the world, I looked into fan housings, and realized that some of the dual fan mods were probably beyond my capabilities ( I'm a sculptor, not an engineer, which should be obvious later). I needed a simple way to get some versatility out of a single fan so I didn't have to monkey too much with the guts of my Mini.

That meant blocking airflow to the part duct, but attempts at modifying the duct were problematic. Not a lot of room down there, and you don't want any tiny hardware that can fail or drag on your print. So instead of blocking the path of the air at the nozzle end, I decide to move the source of the air.

The Idea is pretty simple. Hang the fan mount on a hinge, swing it back to send air to the part duct, or push it closed to send air just to the thermistor. Version 1 was too short in the duct for the fan mount to move freely. Fixed that in version 2, but then ran into some issues with printability. I want to be able to print the parts cleanly on my Mini without supports to keep the inside of the parts nice and smooth, with minimal cleanup.

Version Three was better, but still had some crazy bridging, so I got rid of that for the models you see here, Version 4.

For assembly, you'll need four small screws, a 2mm x 36mm pin for the hinge, and a small torsion spring. As an option, you could use a shorter hinge pin and cap the ends of the hinge with screws to hold the pin in place. A little CA glue might come in handy as well.

This is designed to use the stock 30mm fan, but doesn't have ears for the spring clips or an interface for the thermistor, so it could be easily modified to fit any hot end. I'll be adding a stock hot-end adapter, E3D adapter, and a mod for a 50mm blower fan soon.

Advice is always appreciated, and I'd be interested in any modifications you make.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100

Notes:

I suggest printing this in PETG for flexibility on interlocking internal parts. I don't have much experience with ABS, but it should work as well.

Arrange the parts on the build area with flattest sides down to minimize the need for supports.

Putting it all together....

Once the parts are printed, clean up any threading with a little sandpaper time, paying special attention to the screw seats where the upper main duct meets the part duct and the faces of the hinge. Be careful and don't sand off the bumps that lock together on the inside of the part duct.

First, fit the fan mount into the main duct so the hinge pieces fit together. Insert the 2mm hinge-pin halfway through the hinge. Place the torsion spring (see photo for reference) in the gap in the center of the hinge so that it forces the hinge open, and then pass the hinge-pin through the center of the spring and on into the other half of the hinge.

Holding the hinge closed, mate up the screw seats on the main duct with the matching seats on the part duct and screw the upper and lower halves together (screw from the bottom up). A little CA glue in the gap might not hurt, either. Install the 30mm fan and whatever adapter you need for your hot-end, and you should be good to go.

(This should fit directly onto the Mini stock hot-end as-is if you want to use two self-tapping screws as ears for the spring clips)

Modeled in 123D Design (free version)

Motion testing done in 3D Coat. (if it doesn't work it's their fault)

Test prints printed on MonoPrice Select Mini 3D Printer using e-Sun PETG filament.

remixed_from.author: ryborg
remixed_from.title: Spool Holder for Prusa i3 MK2

title: Prusa i3 mk2 Easy Spool Holder/Rollers - Low Rider Remix

description.text:
Ismael Feliciano released a v2 version of his original Easy Spool Holder, now with rollers and a filament guide.
Not being able to run his design in my enclosure due to height limitations I redesigned my low rider supports to suit the new rollers, incorporating the filament guide and adding some tabs to help keel the spools in place.
I also made the rollers and bolts a bit longer to suit larger spools, up to 96mm.

EXTRA PARTS NEEDED:

  • 4x 608 bearings (any skate/surf shop should carry them, they are very common)

EDIT (2017.02.21):

  • Uploaded the Main Supports to a _V8 with an extra stiff filament guide and a bit taller to cope with full height prints.
  • uploaded the Nuts and Bolts to a _V2 because there was some errors in the file, these are better.

EDIT (2017.02.26):

  • Uploaded the Main Supports to a _V9 with a cleaner design, minus the tabs that did lock up some spools, I'm running these in ABS for a while now and haven't encountered any issues so far, solid!

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15-20%

Notes:

I printed these prototype's using Prusa's Orange PLA but to ensure warping doesn't occur overtime (as enclosures run mildly hot inside), you should print using ABS.

EDIT (2017.02.21): Already did a couple prints using ABS, I got some warping in the supports but overall worked ok after assembled.
I recommend using the updated version files (supports V8 and Nut's n Bolts V2) for better results.

EDIT (2017.02.26): Already did a couple prints using ABS, I got some warping in the supports but overall worked ok after assembled.
I recommend using the updated version files (supports V9 and Nut's n Bolts V2) for better results.

comments.text: Love this design.  Only suggested improvement would be to have a 8mm ID tube to brace the center of the bearing from lateral force applied when you tighten the nut.  This way equal pressure would be applied from the outside (spool bracket arm) and inside (bracing tube). Would allow for free spinning of the bearing.
comments.author: sandnessmj

comments.text:
Not sure I follow your idea, the inside bushing centers with the outer of the bearing, it already free spins quite easily, whatever the force applied on the nut/bolt (which can't be much anyway or the bolt will break).
I'm considering making the filament guide a bit higher to help with untangling on higher prints, although I've yet to encounter a severe limitation, all been working fine.
comments.author: sandnessmj

comments.text: The inside bushing does align, but my bearings don't spin freely as soon as any force is applied by tightening the nut. They still turn, but not as easily. It's not a huge problem, but potentially the nut could vibrate off and the bolt could slide out causing the spool to fall or get jammed up. If there was an intermediate tube between the bearings you could tighten without any lateral force being applied and the bearings would still spin. Might just be an issue with my bearings. In the meantime I'm just going to tack the nut in place with a dab of hot glue.

title: Rubik's 3x3x3 O-type (2) Square One and Square Two

description.text:
It's a derivate of my other O-type cube.
Now the same angle between all cubies so there are more free positions.

Printed in ABS, also PLA should work if carefully sanded.

How to assemble:
Print the round parts, inside there are holes. Cut rods (I've used M3 threaded rods, 3mm filament should work). Glue together (I've used ABS-juice because of my ABS-print). Fix in a vice until glue is dry. Remove plastic blobs, sandpaper if neccessary. Then I have acetone-vaporized all parts to get smooth surfaces. When dry, Check round parts for assembly: M3-screw -> washer under screw head + a little grease -> one round element -> washer between -> next round element -> nylock nut. If ok, unscrew, fill the tracks with the cubies and assemble again. Paint the sides or sticker it, as you like.

If you have problems to glue the round parts: drill from outside and use M3 screws. See red marked area in scad screenshot.

Puzzle system meets the square-2 system (outer rows only). Mid row is annother system.

edit 2017-03-20
I have added Version (3) and (4). Now there are:
Version(1)[thing:1316057] odd angle of the cubies. Only 2 big and 2 small will give 180deg for rotation
Version(2) equal angle between all cubies
Version(3) [here in zip-folder]: cubies in 30deg and 60deg wide
Version(4) [here in zip-folder]: cubies in 60deg and 30deg wide
Version 3 and 4 I don't have printed yet. Version 1 and 2 works with no problems so I am sure version 3 and 4 will do.

A small sprinkler for watering plants.

My first design and thus not unlikely to have flaws in the design. I am to use it on my balcony where I am building an automatic watering system running on a 12 volt battery. The water pump comes from the wiper system on a car and connects to a hose with 5mm inner diameter. This hose is then supposed to connect to several of these sprinklers placed amongst the plants.
ps! I am still waiting for my makerbot to arrive so I have not printed/tested my design yet.

Great model file from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1460737
But there are some holes on the armor. I fixed the hole by using meshmixer!

Important Note: I scale down the model file by a factor of 0.9. If you would like to print the rest parts from the original design, please scale them accordingly.

I was looking for a LED Desk lamp but most lamp comes with a single-strip LED. Anything more fancier than that would generally cost a lot more. I basically wanted a simple & bright lamp that also eliminates shadows when I write. So, I tried designing one.

I've tested using 2 LED torchlight at about 30° apart & it seems to work (eliminating the shadow of my fingers). However, I designed a lamp head joint that is adjustable, just in case I'm wrong :)

Just a disclaimer, I have not tested this as of this writing but I will once I gets the chance. If you have printed it, do give me your feedback on any improvements.

Step 1 - Getting the parts

The attached files are meant to be 3D printed. However, there are items you will need to get from your local stores:

  1. A rocker power-switch or something similar. Its dimension can be retrieved here:
    http://www.farnell.com/cad/1599968.pdf?_ga=1.2425648.1600602482.1474813043

  2. Two LED strip with length of not more than 94mm each. The width should be less than 10mm.

  3. A power (wall-walt) adapter that is sufficient to power your LED strips.

  4. A normal, AWG 16 to 18 will be fine.

  5. Four pairs of M3 bolt & nuts with 2 washers per pair. If possible, get those hand knobs instead of nuts.

Some soldering will be needed.

Step 2 - 3D printing

You'll need to print all the STL parts. Do ensure that you re-position the work piece in your 3D printer's software to minimize support. I've tried to design them to be 3D printer-friendly but some areas are unavoidable.

[Newly Added]
Please take note to adjust the infill for the parts below:

  1. Base.stl - Try to increase the infill as high as possible. Basically, we'll need the base to be heavier. On MakerBot, I'll adjust infill to 80%. I'll probably not go for 100% unless I have heated-bed as the sides might warp, creating an uneven base.

  2. For the rest of the parts, you can go for lesser infill. On MakerBot, I'll adjust infill to 10%.
Step 3 - Assemble them

  1. Please follow the instructions on connecting the LED strips from its manufacturers. For this design, you will basically need to connect in parallel (the red wire from first strip connect to the red wire of the second strip. Same goes to the black wires.)

  2. Connect the red wire from the LED strips to one end of the rocker switch's terminal. Then, connect the other terminal to the power adapter. Most power adapter comes with a 2.1" male socket. Either you could cut that & connect the wires (positive to red & ground to black) or get a female 2.1" socket to wire the ending wires from your LED lamp. *Be sure you do not connect to the wall socket while doing all these! If you are unsure or not confident in performing these electrical activities, get an experience person to do these for you.

  3. Once you've connected & tested that the LED strips lights up when you switch ON, then you can proceed to assemble them.

  4. Paste the LED strips onto the Arms & insert the wires through the end such that the wires are exposed.

  5. Bolt & almost tighten all the joints till it looks like the one in the picture.

  6. There are grooves along the Arms & Base to allow you to nicely tuck in the wires.

  7. The rocker switch should be insert from the top before you connect the wires.

Hopefully, once all these are done, you'll have a nice looking anti-shadow LED lamp!

title: Water cooler/beer tap valve cusp stem

description.text:
This was a part that I couldn't find a precise name for, other than it being part of a cusp seat assembly for a water cooler/beer tap valve handle.   
The bottom ring seats down into a gasket seal for the faucet, and the valve handle slides into the notched area at the top.   
This particular tap was from a beer tube and seemed to be pretty generic. A lot of tap mechanisms seem to work in the same way but some customization may be needed to fit other tap handles. Hack away.

Printed in 3mm ABS with a .5mm j-head nozzle.
Bed temp: 110ÃÂÃÂº
Hotend: 230ÃÂÃÂº
2 perimeters
90% infill
max speed 40mm/s
printed w/support This is a tiny part and strength was an issue as there is pressure placed on both ends when the tap is operated. I printed it slowly to increase adhesion, but at the same time had to apply cooling in order for it to keep its shape. I chose to print it laying horizontally with support so that the force applied to the stem was in line with the grain of the plastic rather than perpendicular to it. My first print was vertical and the bottom ring broke off when I tried to remove the support between the rings.

title: MINI (1st Gen) Key lock button replacement

description.text:
Unfortunately the rubber button on my MINI key decided to tear and then disintegrate...

For anyone else who encounters this problem, I present to you my replacement button!

Simply print both parts (Outer ring and button) then cut out any remaining fragments of the rubber button, leaving only a small engraved ring around a hole (As shown in 2nd picture)

Then slot the outer ring into this hole and push the button through the hole left (With the flange on the bottom to stop it coming loose)
Test the key and if it all works, then remove the button again and apply a small amount of glue to the outer ring and stick it to the key. (I used superglue gel)

Included is Button MK1.1 and Button MK1.2
MK1.1 will need some sanding on the bottom flange, whereas MK1.2 shouldn't.
MK1.2 has a rounded top to the top of the button.

author: jonnybrokenbones

title: External spool holder for the FlashForge Finder 3D printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The FlashForge Finder is compatible with 1.75 mm PLA filament. If you happen to have PLA spools that don't fit inside the build-in filament casing, then this external spool holder makes it easy to fit them on your Finder.

The holder's axle is hollow to accommodate one or more units of the Universal Filament Filter and Lubricator. The end of the axle has a thread that fits the corresponding screw cap. We recommend using this small filter/lubricator to keep the filament clean before it enters the extruder.

Please note that when using this external holder, the filament bypasses the build-in filament detection switch. Therefore the Finder won't be able to sense when the spool runs out of filament and pause the 3D-print. If you use external spools you will need to turn of the filament sensing feature under the settings menu on the machines touchscreen display.

Also included in this thing are pre-sliced ready-to-use .gx files you can copy to a USB stick and print directly on the Finder. Download the file Pre-sliced .gx-files ready-to-print files for FlashForge Finder.zip which contains these files.

Learn more about the FlashForge Finder and get support here.

  • For similar purposes, we have also designed free-standing spool holder: http://thingiverse.com/thing:508896

  • Please also see our Universal Cantilevered Spool Holder for 3D printers
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2297303

    By Creative Tools

    Home - Youtube - Things - #3DBenchy - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Instructables - Instagram - Pinterest - Flickr - LinkedIn #MadeByCreativeTools

Here is a great stellated dodecahedron with a hole in one pyramid that serves as a point for hanging.  A related polyhedron, the first stellation of the icosahedron, is also included.  
The great stellated dodecahedron is usually constructed from 12 pentagrams with 3 meeting at each vertex.  However the method used here replaces each face of an icosahedron with a scaleable trigonal pyramid; a variation of the method used in thing:193876 - Great Dodecahedron as Ornament.  A number of well known polyhedra can be constructed using different scale factors.  They include the great dodecahedron, the decahedron, a Catalan solid called the triakis icosahedron, the first stellation of the icosahedron, (this is a "reversal" of the great dodecahedron) and the great stellated dodecahedron.  
See the openSCAD code.
The stl files require a raft and external support.  On my Replicator they print in under 3 hours.  An openSCAD file which animates the changes between the forms is included.

comments.author: llan

description.text:
Hello,

Size: 10 * 10 cm

This is a design, which is made of 4mm plexiglass plates.

I put a 6mm bar in the middle, with 3 of the connection pieces on it.

Everything can be connected with M2 bolts and nuts of the same size.

I added LEDs to give the project a special effect as you can see on the pictures.
This is done by adding a DC jack and an on/off switch. This is built in in the design.

I did upload the needed DXF files which are required to make this project. For the frontplate, I've made one as an example with 'love', but I added a clear one as well so you can put your own name on it. (Just as I did for my girlfriend Valentine)

If you have questions, feel free to ask.

If you like the design, please leave a LIKE. That's also a motivation to me. :)
Enjoy! :)

This is version 3. It is a standalone or part of the 4 Controllers Stand

The idea is to create 4 of these so 4 controllers can be kept on the table. Those stands should be stackable hence the locking at the back. Two plates (one on top and one on bottom) in the middle between the four stands should be able to hold these together. The model should be easily printable laying on its side to ensure internal stability.

Version 2 required a well set up printer and slow printing speeds in order to print the midle part that during printing acted as supports. This was not the case in my print. This version has gone through quite radical change in the design of the middle.

The front:
The supporting edge was removed as it didn't do anything good after printing version 2
The size of the whole in the front has been increased to reduce material usage.
The "rods" that actually hold the controller were reshaped a bit so that they need less supporting.

The middle:
It will now only have half of the volume. To make it stronger I made it a bit higher in that section. The design could be much simpler but I thought it will look cooler with all those angles.
Since the design of a controller that I used from Sketchup's Warehouse was not exact, the length of the stand became too big. It's reduced with 1cm making it 1cm longer than version 1.

The back:
A pocket was made in the back of the thing so a handle could possibly fit in there at the end of this project.
